citations.narrative:
*** The metal shift door in the Javan Languar enclosure is rusted with some parts flaking off. Rusted surfaces prevent
required cleaning and sanitization and if left can begin to degrade and break down the door. Surfaces in non human
primate enclosures need to be maintained to facilitate cleaning and facilitate care for the animals.
Correct by: Jan 6, 2023

*Several holding areas including the back holding for tiger and cheetah still have metal bars that are rusted with rust
actively flaking off when lightly touched. The base of the walls of cheetah holding have rust that is now breaking down the
metal and breaking off creating sharp edges in the holding area. This amount of rust development does not allow the
enclosures to be properly cleaned and this degree of rust will begin to breakdown the structural integrity of the enclosures.
*The holding area for the Jaguars has a section of exposed ventilation and electrical wires that needs to be closed up.
Exposed ventilation has the potential to end up in the enclosure which could be a hazard to the animals.
*The two shift areas in the pygmy hippo enclosure need to be addressed. The top of both doors has a metal ledge that
has been bent downward, creating sharp edges which pose a potential hazard to the animals.
*The shift doors in the giraffe barn need to be addressed. The top of both doors has a metal ledge that has been
damaged creating sharp edges which pose a potential hazard to the animals.
These areas must be addressed and maintained in good repair to keep the enclosures sound for the safety of the
animals.

***The Capybara have been moved into winter housing that does not provide a pool for the animals to submerge in water.
Capybara are a semi aquatic species and having access to a pool provides the ability for normal and postural adjustments
with adequate freedom of movement including the ability to swim. This aspect of their enclosure needs to be addressed
for the overall health of the animals.
***The camels have been moved into stalls in the red barn for winter housing. The stalls do not provide adequate space
for adequate freedom of movement and do not allow for social adjustments if the animals want to get away from each
other. These stalls should be addressed to provide additional space during the winter season.
Correct by: Jan 6, 2023

The peacocks and a turkey are currently housed in a barn in the drive through park that does not have electricity or lights
and the windows do not provide adequate light to adequately visualize all the birds. Indoor housing facilities must have
lighting that is appropriately distributed and in duration to provide for a normal light cycle for all the birds in the building.
Correct by: Dec 15, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
*** The metal shift door in the Javan Languar enclosure is rusted with some parts flaking off. Rusted surfaces prevent 
required cleaning and sanitization and if left can begin to degrade and break down the door. Surfaces in non human 
primate enclosures need to be maintained to facilitate cleaning and facilitate care for the animals.  
Correct by: Jan 6, 2023 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
*Several holding areas including the back holding for tiger and cheetah still have metal bars that are rusted with rust 
actively flaking off when lightly touched. The base of the walls of cheetah holding have rust that is now breaking down the 
metal and breaking off creating sharp edges in the holding area. This amount of rust development does not allow the 
enclosures to be properly cleaned and this degree of rust will begin to breakdown the structural integrity of the enclosures.  
 
*The holding area for the Jaguars has a section of exposed ventilation and electrical wires that needs to be closed up. 
Exposed ventilation has the potential to end up in the enclosure which could be a hazard to the animals.  
 
*The two shift areas in the pygmy hippo enclosure need to be addressed. The top of both doors has a metal ledge that 
has been bent downward, creating sharp edges which pose a potential hazard to the animals.  
 
*The shift doors in the giraffe barn need to be addressed. The top of both doors has a metal ledge that has been 
damaged creating sharp edges which pose a potential hazard to the animals.  
 
These areas must be addressed and maintained in good repair to keep the enclosures sound for the safety of the 
animals. 
3.128 
   
Space requirements. 
***The Capybara have been moved into winter housing that does not provide a pool for the animals to submerge in water. 
Capybara are a semi aquatic species and having access to a pool provides the ability for normal and postural adjustments

with adequate freedom of movement including the ability to swim. This aspect of their enclosure needs to be addressed 
for the overall health of the animals.  
 
***The camels have been moved into stalls in the red barn for winter housing. The stalls do not provide adequate space 
for adequate freedom of movement and do not allow for social adjustments if the animals want to get away from each 
other. These stalls should be addressed to provide additional space during the winter season.  
Correct by: Jan 6, 2023 
3.151(c) 
   
Facilities, indoor 
The peacocks and a turkey are currently housed in a barn in the drive through park that does not have electricity or lights 
and the windows do not provide adequate light to adequately visualize all the birds. Indoor housing facilities must have 
lighting that is appropriately distributed and in duration to provide for a normal light cycle for all the birds in the building.  
Correct by: Dec 15, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
